message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Debate "character" for 德">
The author is considering "character" for 德. Those who voted against it — what is your single strongest objection to "character"? Those who voted for it — what is its single strongest advantage?

Also: we now know 性 does NOT appear as a standalone technical term in the collection, so the "nature" collision concern is off the table.

Brief responses — one strongest point each.
</teammate-message>

input.summary: Strongest objection to "character": underdetermines in the key sentence
input.content:
**Strongest objection: "character" does not carry enough philosophical weight to survive the author's key generalizing move.**

The sentence "凡事诸物皆有其德" -- "all things have their character" -- is philosophically flat. "Character" in English defaults to personality/temperament for persons and to vague description for things ("the character of the landscape"). It does not convey that 德 is what *makes something what it is* -- the defining principle. "All things have their virtue" immediately signals philosophical tradition (Aristotelian arete, Aquinas's virtus) and primes the reader to think in terms of essential functioning, not mere description.

That said, if the team moves toward "character," I would not object strongly. It is neutral enough that the TN and the author's own text can do the heavy lifting. My concern is only that it gives the reader *less* to work with at the starting gate than "virtue" does.

content.text: Strongest objection to "character": it is philosophically flat. "All things have their character" reads as vague description, whereas "all things have their virtue" signals philosophical tradition and primes the reader to think about essential functioning. "Character" gives the reader less to work with, though I would not strongly object if the team converges on it. Standing by.
